natural problem: How many ways are there to arrange the letters of the word $\text{BA}_1\text{N}_1\text{A}_2\text{N}_2\text{A}_3$, in which the three A's and the two N's are considered different?
natural solution: This is counting the number of ways that six distinct objects can be put in order, so there are $6! = \boxed{720}$ different arrangements.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. fact n)"
shows  "P 6 = 720"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange the letters of the word $\text{BA}_1\text{N}_1\text{A}_2\text{N}_2\text{A}_3$, in which the three A's and the two N's are considered different? The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 This is counting the number of ways that six distinct objects can be put in order, so there are $6! = \boxed{720}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. fact n)"
shows  "P 6 = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of the factorial function $P(n) = n!$ when $n = 6$. The final answer is $720$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 720"
shows  "card {p. permutes p (insert 1 (insert 2 (insert 3 (insert 4 (insert 5 (insert 6 {}))))))} = n"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange the letters of the word $\text{BA}_1\text{N}_1\text{A}_2\text{N}_2\text{A}_3$, in which the three A's and the two N's are considered different? The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 This is counting the number of ways that six distinct objects can be put in order, so there are $6! = \boxed{720}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 720"
shows  "card {p. permutes p (insert 1 (insert 2 (insert 3 (insert 4 (insert 5 (insert 6 {}))))))} = n"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many permutations are there for the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}? The final answer is 720.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. factorial n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * factorial (n - 1))"
and h1 : "factorial 6 = 720"
shows  "720 = card {p :: (nat \<Rightarrow> char). permutes {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} p \<and> p 1 = CHAR ''B'' \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {2, 4, 6}. p i = CHAR ''A'') \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {3, 5}. p i = CHAR ''N'')}"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange the letters of the word $\text{BA}_1\text{N}_1\text{A}_2\text{N}_2\text{A}_3$, in which the three A's and the two N's are considered different? The final Answer is 720
 ### Proof
 This is counting the number of ways that six distinct objects can be put in order, so there are $6! = \boxed{720}$ different arrangements.
 *)

theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. factorial n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * factorial (n - 1))"
and h1 : "factorial 6 = 720"
shows  "720 = card {p :: (nat \<Rightarrow> char). permutes {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} p \<and> p 1 = CHAR ''B'' \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {2, 4, 6}. p i = CHAR ''A'') \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {3, 5}. p i = CHAR ''N'')}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many ways can the letters 'B', 'A', 'A', 'N', 'A', 'N' be arranged if 'B' is in the first position, 'A's are in the even positions, and 'N's are in the odd positions? The final answer is 720.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ways :: nat and fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. fact n = (if n = 0 then 1 else n * fact (n - 1))"
and h1 : "ways = fact 6"
shows  "ways = 720"

(* ### Problem
 How many ways are there to arrange the letters of the word $\text{BA}_1\text{N}_1\text{A}_2\text{N}_2\text{A}_3$, in which the three A's and the two N's are considered different? The final Answer is 720

 *)

and h1 : "ways = fact 6"
shows  "ways = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the factorial of 6, denoted as $6!$. The final answer is 720.
